title: Judgments on Israel's Neighbors
shortSummary: Ezekiel 25 records God's pronouncement of judgment against Israel's neighboring nations—Ammon, Moab, Edom, and the Philistines—because of their hostility and rejoicing over Israel's calamity. These prophecies reveal God's sovereignty and justice, demonstrating that He will punish those who oppose His people and defile His name.
timeline: c. 593-571 BC - During the Babylonian exile, when Ezekiel prophesied against Israel's neighbors

keyCharacters.name: Ammonites
keyCharacters.description: A neighboring nation east of Israel, condemned for rejoicing over Israel's desolation and profaning God's sanctuary.

keyCharacters.name: Moabites
keyCharacters.description: Neighbors southeast of Israel, judged for mocking Judah and aligning with Ammonites against Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Edomites
keyCharacters.description: Descendants of Esau, located south of Israel, punished for taking vengeance on Judah and acting spitefully.

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: Sea coast people west of Israel, condemned for their longstanding hatred and revenge against Israel.

definitions.definition: A title used by God to address Ezekiel, emphasizing his humanity and role as a prophet.
Likely a Philistine subgroup or mercenaries associated with the Philistines, targeted for destruction.
The capital city of the Ammonites, prophesied to become a stable for camels, symbolizing desolation.
A term used to describe nations or peoples who do not worship the true God, often used here for Israel’s enemies.

outline.heading: Judgment Against the Ammonites
outline.description: God commands Ezekiel to prophesy against the Ammonites for their rejoicing over Israel’s destruction and desecration of His sanctuary. Their land and capital, Rabbah, will be given over to eastern peoples, showing God’s judgment and sovereignty.

outline.heading: Judgment Against Moab
outline.description: Because Moab mocked Judah and aligned with Ammon, God declares He will open Moab’s border cities to invasion and give them to the Ammonites, erasing Moab’s remembrance among nations.

outline.heading: Judgment Against Edom
outline.description: Edom is condemned for taking vengeance on Judah. God promises to destroy both man and beast, desolate Teman, and use Israel to execute His vengeance, demonstrating divine justice.

outline.heading: Judgment Against the Philistines
outline.description: The Philistines are judged for their spiteful revenge and longstanding hatred toward Israel. God will cut off the Cherethims and destroy the coastal remnants, executing great vengeance to reveal His sovereignty.

application: Recognize that God is sovereign over all nations and will bring justice against those who oppose His people and purposes.
Avoid rejoicing over the misfortunes of others, especially God’s people, as such attitudes provoke divine judgment.
Trust in God’s righteous vengeance rather than taking personal revenge, knowing He will right wrongs in His perfect timing.
Pray for God’s protection over His people and for the repentance of those who oppose Him.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the Lord GOD; Because thou hast clapped thine hands, and stamped with the feet, and rejoiced in heart with all thy despite against the land of Israel;
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the reason for God's judgment—the Ammonites' rejoicing over Israel's destruction, showing that God judges attitudes as well as actions.

keyVerses.text: And I will execute judgments upon Moab; and they shall know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: God’s judgments serve to reveal His identity and sovereignty to all nations, emphasizing that His justice is purposeful and redemptive.

keyVerses.text: And I will lay my vengeance upon Edom by the hand of my people Israel: and they shall do in Edom according to mine anger and according to my fury; and they shall know my vengeance, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God’s use of Israel to execute His vengeance, underscoring His control over history and fulfillment of His promises.

keyVerses.text: And I will execute great vengeance upon them with furious rebukes; and they shall know that I am the LORD, when I shall lay my vengeance upon them.
keyVerses.significance: The final verse summarizes the chapter’s theme: God’s vengeance is sure and powerful, and it reveals His lordship to all.
